Package wt.query

Provides generic support for defining datastore independent queries.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    ColumnExpression
    This interface defines an arbitrary expression that can be used to specify a "column" in a SQL SELECT, ORDER BY, GROUP BY or WHERE clause.

    This interface defines an expression that can be used in a SQL statement.

    This interface defines an expression that can be used in a SQL ORDER BY clause.

    This interface specifies the abstractions necessary to establish a persistent paging session.

    This interface defines an expression that can be used as an operand in a relational expression in a SQL WHERE clause.

    Delegate interface for search attribute lists for HTML Local Search.
    TableExpression
    This interface defines an expression that can be used to specify a "table" in a SQL FROM clause.
    WhereExpression
    This interface represents an expression that can be used in a SQL WHERE clause.

Package wt.query Description

Provides generic support for defining datastore independent queries. Queries are constructed programatically be constructing QuerySpec and CompoundQuerySpec objects and using them as arguments to PersistenceManager query methods.

The ClassAttribute and SearchCondition classes contain fields and methods that reference a query object's persistent column in the datastore.

The QuerySpec supports methods for using datastore based functions (SQLFunction) and keywords (KeywordExpression). The following tables describe how Windchill supports these expressions for each supported datastore.

  • Functions
  • Keywords

Concurrency Support

Queries may be processed using concurrently executing threads where background processing threads come from a pool that the persistence layer manages. The foreground thread first executes the Statement. If a thread is available from the pool, then the ResultSet instances are passed to this background thread. The foreground thread processes access control (if applicable), and executes ResultProcessor.addElement(java.lang.Object) (the default ResultProcessor accumulates result elements into a QueryResult). The background thread fetches results from the ResultSet and builds the result objects (e.g. builds a full Persistable from individual primitive attributes). The foreground and background threads execute concurrently and communicate using a BlockingQueue.

Queries that are best suited for concurrent processing are those where the overall processing is split evenly between the foreground and background threads. A simple priority mechanism is implemented to make some queries more likely to be executed concurrently. The calling code may also explicitly request that a query should have higher priority. This is done by calling the method StatementSpec.setConcurrentEnabled(boolean).

For more information on configuring concurrency support, see the wt.pom.resultSetThreadPool.* properties in properties.html and wt.pom.concurrent.* properties in loggers.html.

Examples

Query for Parts Returning the Name 

QuerySpec query = new QuerySpec();
int classIndex = qs.appendClassList(WTPart.class, false /* Do not select full Persistable */);
ClassAttribute nameAttribute = new ClassAttribute(WTPart.class, WTPart.NAME);
query.appendSelect(nameAttribute, new int[] { classIndex }, false /* select and return attribute */);

Query for Usage Links with a Usage ObjectIdentifier

In this example, the WTPartUsageLink "uses" role is the role B. 

ObjectIdentifier usesOid = ...;
     
QuerySpec query = new QuerySpec();
int classIndex = qs.appendClassList(WTPartUsageLink.class, true /* Select full Persistable */);
SearchCondition condition = new SearchCondition(WTPartUsageLink.class, 
  BinaryLink.ROLE_BOBJECT_REF + "." + ObjectReference.KEY, SearchCondition.EQUAL, usesOid);
query.appendWhere(condition, new int[] { classIndex });
